1.text: Like snow in summer and rain at harvest, honor does not befit a fool.

2.text: Like a fluttering sparrow or darting swallow, an undeserved curse does not come to rest.

3.text: A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the backs of fools!

4.text: Do not answer a fool according to his folly, or you yourself will be like him.

5.text: Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he become wise in his own eyes.

6.text: Like cutting off one’s own feet or drinking violence is the sending of a message by the hand of a fool.

7.text: Like lame legs hanging limp is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.

8.text: Like binding a stone into a sling is the giving of honor to a fool.

9.text: Like a thorn that goes into the hand of a drunkard is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.

10.text: Like an archer who wounds at random is he who hires a fool or passerby.

11.text: As a dog returns to its vomit, so a fool repeats his folly.

12.text: Do you see a man who is wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.

13.text: The slacker says, “A lion is in the road! A fierce lion roams the public square!”

14.text: As a door turns on its hinges, so the slacker turns on his bed.

15.text: The slacker buries his hand in the dish; it wearies him to bring it back to his mouth.

16.text: The slacker is wiser in his own eyes than seven men who answer discreetly.

17.text: Like one who grabs a dog by the ears is a passerby who meddles in a quarrel not his own.

18.text: Like a madman shooting firebrands and deadly arrows,

19.text: so is the man who deceives his neighbor and says, “I was only joking!”

20.text: Without wood, a fire goes out; without gossip, a conflict ceases.

21.text: Like charcoal for embers and wood for fire, so is a quarrelsome man for kindling strife.

22.text: The words of a gossip are like choice morsels that go down into the inmost being.

23.text: Like glaze covering an earthen vessel are burning lips and a wicked heart.

24.text: A hateful man disguises himself with his speech, but he lays up deceit in his heart.

25.text: When he speaks graciously, do not believe him, for seven abominations fill his heart.

26.text: Though his hatred is concealed by deception, his wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.

27.text: He who digs a pit will fall into it, and he who rolls a stone will have it roll back on him.

28.text: A lying tongue hates those it crushes, and a flattering mouth causes ruin.
